channel.title: Posts on Rob Wiederstein -- a blog about data
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Rob Wiederstein -- a blog about data

item.title: Insert HTML Widgets in Blogdown
item.description: There were two main reasons for moving to blogdown. First, I needed a blogging platform that moved seemlessly between R code and its output. It had to be easy to show the connection between the code that was used and its effect on the data. Put the two side-by-side and people can understand what happened. Itâ€™s how I learn off the console.

item.title: Try Syntax Highlighting
item.description: a <- 1:10 paste("-dog", a, sep ="") ## [1] "-dog1" "-dog2" "-dog3" "-dog4" "-dog5" "-dog6" "-dog7" "-dog8" ## [9] "-dog9" "-dog10" plot(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$hp, main = "Example Plot")

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can place an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.
